title: Video Games Helped Ukrainian Bradley Gunner Win Duel With Russian T-90M Tank
text:
TCH screencap The Ukrainian Bradley Fighting Vehicle gunner whose attack on a Russian T-90M Breakthrough tank was captured in a viral video says playing video games helped prepare him for that engagement.
In an interview with the Ukrainian TCH media outlet , that soldier, identified only as â€œSerhiy,â€ explained heâ€™d just recently returned to Ukraine in December from Bradley training in Germany. Also the vehicle commander, he and his driver, Oleksandr, were only on their second mission together. Members of the 47th Separate Mechanized Brigade, their job was to protect troops in a trench under fire from Russian tanks.
A more personal and detailed interview with the crew of the Ukrainian Bradley which took on a russian T-90M. Also goes over using American-supplied Bradley IFVs in conditions of the Ukrainian winter ğŸ’ª pic.twitter.com/GtSGt8Cxiq
â€” WarTranslated (Dmitri) (@wartranslated) January 19, 2024 You can read all about the Bradley and what it brings to the fight in Ukraine in this recent article of ours.
Going up against a heavily armored T-90M, Russiaâ€™s most advanced frontline tank armed with a 125mm cannon, with the Bradleyâ€™s 25mm chain gun was risky, said Serhiy.
â€œYes, it was very scary,â€ he said. â€œBut I think we did well.â€
One of several direct hits Bradley Fighting Vehicle gunner Serhiy was able to land on a Russian T-90M tank. ( TCH screencap) â€œI canâ€™t express what it means to see a tank in the sights,â€ said Serhiy. â€œIn training, I was saying, â€˜God forbid I see a tank in the sights.â€™ It so happened that I did, and very close.â€
â€œThere was another crew that came first. It didnâ€™t work out, so we had to muster up the courage and go.â€
Serhiy didnâ€™t explain what happened to that other Bradley, which is seen on the second video we wrote about yesterday, which you can see below.
Higher quality footage of a pair of Ukrainian M2A2 Bradley IFVs from the 47th Mechanized successfully dueling a Russian T-90M in Stepove, disabling it, with a follow up FPV munition strike causing the crew to abandon the damaged vehicle. pic.twitter.com/Vor8IuVlBZ
â€” OSINTtechnical (@Osinttechnical) January 13, 2024 Regardless, Serhiyâ€™s Bradley took over the job of attacking the tank.
â€œWe fired with all we couldâ€ with the Bradleyâ€™s Bushmaster M242 25mm automatic cannon â€˜s armor piercing rounds.
Then there was a problem with those rounds, he said, without offering details. This is when his experience with video games kicked in.
â€œBut as I played video games, I remembered everything. Both how to hit and where. I could stop him at any cost.â€
Many video games over the years have highlighted the need to hit certain armored vehicles, especially tanks, in areas where their armor is thinnest and/or critical components are more exposed. Tanks are most heavily armored in the frontal hemisphere and less so in the rear. Other weak points exist, on the sides between the turret and the hull, for instance. Simply blinding the tank by destroying its sensors can result in a mission kill, leaving it repairable but useless on the battlefield, too.
Confirming what two armor experts told us after seeing a video of the battle , Serhiy said that he switched to another type of round and began aiming for the tankâ€™s optics. He didnâ€™t specify what kind of round, but as our experts said , the Bradleys usually have anti-armor and high explosive rounds.
â€œDue to issues with anti-armor, I started blinding him so he couldnâ€™t leave,â€ said Serhiy. As we suspected, he achieved a mission kill on the tank by knocking out its optics.
There are three things you can watch forever. Like this Ukrainian M2 Bradley IFV obliterating a Â«no-analogueÂ» russian T-90M tank.

â€œIâ€™d say he is more important than me even though I am the gunner and commander,â€ said Serhiy. â€œIf he gets me out, I am happy.â€
The men were interviewed at an ad-hoc roadside maintenance area in Avdiivka, according to TCH .
As mechanics worked on the track section of one Bradley, another drove by, bearing holes in its side skirt armor caused by shrapnel from a mine that exploded nearby, the reporter explained.
â€œLike an F1 car, they come, we quickly fix and they go,â€ one of the mechanics said.
A Ukrainian mechanic working on a damaged Bradley Fighting Vehicle near Avdiivka, Donetsk Oblast. ( TCH screencap) As they stood beside their Bradley, one of nearly 200 promised by the U.S., the two men praised the vehicle.
â€œThis vehicle ruins enemy plans,â€ said Serhiy. â€œThey really want to get us.â€
Serhiy (left) and Oleksandr are interviewed outside their Bradley Fighting Vehicle (TCH screencap) Given that Russia shows no signs of backing off its full-scale invasion, itâ€™s very likely they will have another shot at Serhiy and his crew very soon.
